source.query: isometric push up hold muscles worked
source.raw_text:
An Isometric Push-Up Hold builds static strength in the chest (pectorals), shoulders (anterior deltoids), and triceps, while intensely engaging the core (abs, obliques) and back stabilizers (lats, serratus anterior) to maintain a rigid, straight body line, preventing sagging and promoting joint stability through sustained tension, not movement. The movement pattern is a static, closed-chain push, requiring significant core bracing and focus on maintaining proper alignment (hollow body, tucked elbows) against gravity. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers (Pushing Muscles): 

    • Pectoralis Major: The chest muscles, heavily recruited to push against the floor. 
    • Anterior Deltoids: Front of the shoulders, assisting in arm extension. 
    • Triceps: Back of the upper arms, extending the elbow joint. 

• Stabilizers: 

    • Core (Rectus Abdominis, Obliques, Transverse Abdominis): Braces the spine and pelvis, preventing sagging. 
    • Serratus Anterior: Helps protract the shoulder blades and stabilize the shoulder girdle. 
    • Latissimus Dorsi: Back muscles that help keep elbows tucked in (imagining holding pencils). 
    • Glutes & Hamstrings: Engaged to keep the legs locked and the body straight. [1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 8]  

Movement Pattern 

• Type: Isometric (static contraction with no joint movement). 
• Action: Holding a fixed position, typically halfway down in a push-up (chest just above the floor) or at the top. 
• Key Cues: 

    • Maintain a straight line from head to heels (no sagging hips or piking). 
    • Engage the core and squeeze the glutes. 
    • Keep elbows tucked at about a 45-degree angle, not flared out. 
    • Actively push the floor away (or hold tension) to keep muscles engaged. 

• Benefit: Increases time under tension, builds foundational strength, improves joint stability, and enhances mind-muscle connection, making dynamic push-ups feel easier. [2, 3, 9, 10, 11]
